title: USS Seagull (AMS-55)
text:
USS "Seagull" (MCS(O)-55/AMS-55/YMS-402) was a built for the <a href="United%20States%20Navy">United States Navy</a> during <a href="World%20War%20II">World War II</a>.
History.
"Seagull" was laid down as "YMS-402" on 24 July 1942 by <a href="Henry%20B.%20Nevins%2C%20Inc.">Henry B. Nevins, Inc.</a>, <a href="City%20Island%2C%20Bronx">City Island, Bronx</a>; launched on 17 April 1943; and commissioned on 26 June 1943, Lt. (JG.) J.W. Gaines, <a href="USNR">USNR</a>, in command.
In mid-August 1943, "YMS-402" reported for duty in the <a href="Eastern%20Sea%20Frontier">Eastern Sea Frontier</a>. For the next year, she operated out of the Naval Frontier Base, <a href="Tompkinsville%2C%20Staten%20Island">Tompkinsville, Staten Island</a>, <a href="New%20York%20%28state%29">New York</a>.
On 28 August 1944, she departed that base for <a href="San%20Diego%2C%20California">San Diego, California</a>, and duty in the central <a href="Pacific%20Ocean">Pacific</a>. Arriving at <a href="Eniwetok">Eniwetok</a>, <a href="Marshall%20Islands">Marshall Islands</a>, on 20 November, the motor <a href="Minesweeper%20%28ship%29">minesweeper</a>, as a unit of <a href="Mine%20Squadron">Mine Squadron</a> 102, remained in the <a href="Marshall%20Islands">Marshall</a>-<a href="Gilbert%20Islands">Gilberts</a> force for the next nine months, conducting local <a href="Minesweeper%20%28ship%29">minesweeping</a>, escort, and patrol operations, and making an occasional escort into the <a href="Caroline%20Islands">Western Carolines</a>. After the cessation of hostilities in the <a href="Pacific%20Ocean">Pacific</a>, she prepared for postwar minesweeping activities; and, at the end of August 1945, she sailed for <a href="Okinawa">Okinawa</a> and <a href="Japan">Japan</a>.
During the fall, she participated in the opening of <a href="Nagoya">Nagoya</a> and <a href="Wakayama%2C%20Wakayama">Wakayama</a>; and, with the new year, 1946, she headed back to the <a href="United%20States">United States</a>. After stops in the <a href="Marshall%20Islands">Marshalls</a> and in the <a href="Hawaiian%20Islands">Hawaiian Islands</a>, she arrived at <a href="San%20Pedro%2C%20California">San Pedro, California</a>, in early April. She remained on the <a href="West%20Coast%20of%20the%20United%20States">west coast</a> into the summer; and, at the end of June, she sailed for <a href="New%20York%20City">New York</a>, where she was decommissioned on 1 August 1946.
Placed in service again, "YMS-402" departed New York on 30 October and moved north to the <a href="Saint%20Lawrence%20River">St. Lawrence</a>, whence she proceeded to <a href="Buffalo%2C%20New%20York">Buffalo</a>, where she served as a <a href="United%20States%20Naval%20Reserve">naval reserve</a> <a href="School%20ship">training ship</a> until after the outbreak of <a href="Korean%20War">war in Korea</a>. Named USS "Seagull" and redesignated AMS-55 on 1 September 1947 and recommissioned on 10 May 1950, the former YMS returned to the <a href="Atlantic%20Ocean">Atlantic</a> in September 1951 and took up training duties in the <a href="5th%20Naval%20district">5th Naval district</a>. Initially based at <a href="Norfolk%2C%20Virginia">Norfolk, Virginia</a>, and then at the Mine Warfare School, <a href="Yorktown%2C%20Virginia">Yorktown, Virginia</a>.
She continued to operate out of the <a href="Hampton%20Roads">Hampton Roads</a>/<a href="Virginia%20Capes">Virginia Capes</a> area through 1954. Then, in 1955, "Seagull", redesignated "MSC(O)-55" on 7 February, was transferred to <a href="Charleston%2C%20South%20Carolina">Charleston, South Carolina</a>, whence, for the remainder of her career, she conducted operations which took her along the southeastern <a href="East%20Coast%20of%20the%20United%20States">Atlantic seaboard</a>, along the ‘<a href="Gulf%20Coast%20of%20the%20United%20States">gulf coast</a>, and into the <a href="Caribbean%20Sea">Caribbean</a> as a unit of <a href="MinRon">MinRon</a> 4.
In mid-July 1957, the coastal minesweeper departed Charleston for <a href="Philadelphia%2C%20Pennsylvania">Philadelphia</a>, where she was decommissioned on 11 October and placed in reserve. Her name was struck from the <a href="Naval%20Vessel%20Register">Naval Vessel Register</a> on 1 November 1959.
Awards and honors.
"YMS-402" earned one <a href="battle%20star">battle star</a> for her post-World War II minesweeping activities.
